translated: Udāna 3.9
The Collection of Long Discourses 10. The Crafts
Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Park.

original: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṁ maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānaṁ sannipatitānaṁ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena sambahulānam bhikkhūnam pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkantānam maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānam sannipatitānam ayam antarākathā udapādi
translated: Now on that occasion, after their meal, on returning from their alms round, a number of monks were sitting gathered together in the assembly hall, and this discussion had arisen among them:

analyzed: kaḥ nu khalu āvuso sippam jānāti
translated: “Who here knows a craft?
Who has trained in what craft?
What is the best of crafts?”
Some said,
“The craft of elephant-craft is the best of crafts.”
Some said,
“The craft of horse-craft is the best of crafts.”
Some said,
“The craft of chariot-craft is the best of crafts.”
Some said,
“The craft of archery is the best of crafts.”
Some said,
“The craft of sword-fighting is the best of crafts.”
Some said,

analyzed: muddā sippam sippānam agganti 🔽ekacce evam ahasu
translated: “The craft of calculation is the best of crafts.”
“Counting is the best skill.”
Some said,
“Calculation is the best skill.”
Some said,
“Writing is the best skill.”
Some said,
“Poetry is the best skill.”
Some said,
“The worldly knowledge of astrology is the best skill.”
Some said,
“The knowledge of the marks of a Great Man is the best skill.”

original: Ayañcarahi tesaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ antarākathā hoti vippakatā.
analyzed: ayam carahi tesam bhikkhūnam antarākathā hoti vippakatā
translated: But then their discussion was interrupted.

original: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena maṇḍalamāḷo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā sāyanha samayam paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitaḥ yena maṇḍalamāḷo tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi
translated: In the evening, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the round pavilion, where he sat down on the prepared seat
and addressed the monks:

original: “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā, kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
analyzed: kāya nuttha bhikkhave etarahi kathāya sannisinnā kā ca pana vaḥ antarākathā vippakatā ati
translated: “Monks, what were you sitting talking about just now? What was your discussion that was interrupted?”

original: “Idha, bhante, amhākaṁ pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṁ maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānaṁ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
analyzed: idha bhante amhākam pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkantānam maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānam ayam antarākathā udapādi
translated: “Just now, after our meal, on returning from our alms round, we were sitting together in the attendance hall when this discussion arose:

analyzed: kaḥ nu khalu āvuso sippam jānāti
translated: ‘Who here knows a craft?
Who has trained in which craft?🔽Which craft is the best?’🔽Some said this, others said that.🔽Some said:
‘The elephant craft is the best craft.’
Others said:
‘The horse craft is the best craft.’
Others said:
‘The chariot craft is the best craft.’
Others said:
‘The bow craft is the best craft.’
Others said:
‘The sword craft is the best craft.’
Others said:
‘The staff craft is the best craft.’
Others said:
‘The calculation craft is the best craft.’
Others said:
‘The counting craft is the best craft.’
Others said:
‘The reckoning craft is the best craft.’
Others said:
‘The writing craft is the best craft.’
Others said:
‘The art of poetry is the best of the arts.’
Some said,
‘The art of commerce is the best of the arts.’
Some said,
‘The art of archery is the best of the arts.’

original: Ayaṁ kho no, bhante, antarākathā hoti vippakatā, atha bhagavā anuppatto”ti.
analyzed: ayam kho naḥ bhante antarākathā hoti vippakatā atha bhagavā anuppatto ti
translated: This was our discussion that was interrupted when you arrived.”

original: “Na khvetaṁ, bhikkhave, tumhākaṁ patirūpaṁ kulaputtānaṁ saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitānaṁ yaṁ tumhe evarūpiṁ kathaṁ katheyyātha.
analyzed: na khveta bhikkhave tumhākam patirūpam kula puttānam saddhā agārasma anagāriyam pabbajitānam yam tumhe evarūpim katham katheyyātha
translated: “It’s not suitable, monks, for you gentlemen who have gone forth in such a well-expounded Dhamma and Discipline to speak such talk.
When you’re gathered together, you should do one of two things:

original: dhammī vā kathā ariyo vā tuṇhībhāvo”ti.
analyzed: dhammī vā kathā ariyaḥ vā tuṇhībhāvo ti
translated: either discuss the Teaching or maintain noble silence.”

original: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṁ viditvā tāyaṁ velāyaṁ imaṁ udānaṁ udānesi:
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā etam attham viditvā tāyam velāyam imam udānam udānesi
translated: Then, knowing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
“The monk who lives without craft, who’s quick to understand, who desires the good,
who’s restrained in sense faculties, free in every way,
who wanders homeless, without possessions, without expectations,

analyzed: hitvā mānam ekacaraḥ sa bhikkhu iti
translated: having given up conceit, he’s a monk who goes alone.”
The ninth.
